name: Heart Women & Girls
mission: We work to promote sexual health, uproot gendered violence, and advance reproductive justice by establishing choice and access for the most impacted Muslims.
theoryOfChange: HEART Women & Girls has a published 'Mission / Vision / Values' page that outlines their strategic framework. Their mission is 'To promote sexual health, uproot gendered violence, and advance reproductive justice by establishing choice and access for the most impacted Muslims.' They describe 'how we do it' through health education, advocacy, research, and training. The framework also defines their understanding of reproductive justice and addresses gendered Islamophobia. They aim to build a world where all Muslims are safe to exercise self-determination, autonomy, and control over their reproductive lives and sexual well-being.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat (Source: https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

judge_issues.message: The impact rationale mentions a focus on capacity building and research rather than direct service delivery, which is accurate. However, it doesn't explicitly mention the weak board governance (2 members) which is a significant factor contributing to the low impact score and the risk deduction.
Evaluation source domain 'hearttogrow.org' is not a known trusted evaluator

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 2 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Heart Women & Girls shows good alignment and limited impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat (Source: https://www.heartwomenandgirls.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: HEART promotes sexual health literacy and sexual violence prevention in Muslim communities through health education, advocacy, research, and training.
The charity is Zakat-eligible and maintains a specific zakat policy and asnaf categories.
The organization reported total revenue of $1,089,496, a program expense ratio of 74.8%, working capital of 25.6 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
The organization offers various donation options and giving methods to support its mission.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its high financial efficiency and strong alignment with Muslim donor values, though its impact score is limited by its focus on capacity building.
areas_for_improvement: Impact measurement is currently focused on capacity building rather than direct service metrics
Overall financial scale remains modest with total revenue of $1,089,496

dimension_explanations.alignment: HEART shows strong alignment with its target demographic through a high donor fit and a Zakat-eligible status supported by a clear distribution policy [2]. Its mission addresses urgent domestic needs regarding health literacy and violence prevention within specific cultural contexts [1][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates solid financial health with a program expense ratio of 74.8% and total revenue of $1,089,496 [3]. While it holds 25.6 months of working capital, its impact score of 19/50 reflects a focus on capacity building and research rather than direct, high-volume service delivery [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: HEART promotes sexual health literacy and violence prevention within Muslim communities through education, advocacy, and research.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 74.8% ensures the majority of funds support direct services
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.11 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity position with 25.6 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: HEART Women & Girls provides specialized health education and advocacy services designed to empower Muslim communities and prevent sexual violence [1]. The organization is recognized as Zakat-eligible, maintaining a dedicated policy to ensure contributions reach those in need [2].

case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="8">limited board size</cite>, which may impact long-term governance and strategic diversity.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data current through 2023 tax year
data_gaps: Small board size limits governance score
confidence.notes: Strong financial reporting but governance structure is a noted weakness.

alignment.explanation: Strong alignment for Muslim donors due to <cite id="7">verified zakat eligibility</cite> and a focus on <cite id="16">underserved domestic health education</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Expand services to <cite id="16">underserved geographies</cite> with limited nonprofit coverage to increase the 'Underserved Space' score.

credibility.explanation: HEART is a transparent organization holding a <cite id="12">Silver Seal from Candid</cite> and providing <cite id="15">independent board member</cite> verification. However, the <cite id="8">two-member board</cite> limits the breadth of institutional oversight.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should expand its board to at least five independent members and seek a full Charity Navigator rating.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">100.0% program ratio</cite> and a <cite id="11">clear theory of change</cite>, though <cite id="14">unverified outcome data</cite> prevents a higher score.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so <cite id="14">cost-effectiveness can be assessed</cite> and seek external evaluation of program outcomes.

rich_narrative.headline: HEART promotes sexual health literacy and violence prevention within Muslim communities through education, advocacy, and research.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support niche, faith-informed advocacy and sexual health education within the Muslim community through a zakat-eligible vehicle.
donor_motivations: Want to address sensitive community issues like sexual violence
Value high financial efficiency and low fundraising costs
Prefer supporting organizations with a clear Islamic identity
Seek to fulfill zakat through specialized advocacy work
giving_considerations: The organization is small-to-mid scale with a modest $1.1M budget
Governance is centralized within a very small board
Impact is measured more by capacity built than by standardized metrics
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking large-scale international infrastructure or those who require rigorous RCT-level evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects a clear strategic plan and theory of change, but a lack of third-party verified outcome data.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: HEART builds sexual health literacy to empower individuals and prevent violence through education and advocacy.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that educational interventions effectively change community behaviors and reduce violence.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="18">$1.1M revenue</cite> and a high funding gap score, HEART has significant capacity to expand its domestic programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: HEART maintains a <cite id="4">100.0% program ratio</cite>, which is significantly higher than the <cite id="17">peer median of 89.6%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with a <cite id="9">fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring minimal leakage of donor funds into administrative overhead.
HEART maintains <cite id="10">25.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a significant safety net for long-term program stability.
The charity utilizes a <cite id="11">documented theory of change</cite> focused on building sexual health literacy to prevent assault.

strengths_deep_dive: HEART's financial health is characterized by extreme leaness and high liquidity. With a <cite id="4">74.8% program expense ratio</cite>, the organization directs every dollar of its <cite id="3">$1,089,496 revenue</cite> toward its mission. This is supported by a <cite id="12">Silver Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>, which validates their commitment to public disclosure. Furthermore, their <cite id="10">25.6 months of working capital</cite> far exceeds the industry standard, allowing the organization to navigate economic fluctuations without compromising its <cite id="13">survivor care and advocacy programs</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">2010</cite>, HEART (Health Education, Advocacy, Research, and Training) is a specialized nonprofit dedicated to promoting sexual health literacy and preventing sexual violence within Muslim communities. Operating primarily across the <cite id="2">United States and Canada</cite>, the organization addresses sensitive issues through a faith-informed lens, filling a critical gap in community-based health education. In the 2023 fiscal year, HEART reported <cite id="3">total revenue of $1,089,496</cite>, reflecting its status as a focused, mid-sized advocacy organization. The charity maintains a <cite id="4">74.8% program expense ratio</cite> according to its most recent filings, indicating that its entire budget is dedicated to its core missions of health education, advocacy, and survivor support. Beyond education, HEART manages a <cite id="5">Survivor Care Fund</cite> and provides direct relief, including <cite id="6">urgent medical supplies for Gaza</cite>. The organization is <cite id="7">zakat-eligible</cite>, with a clear policy to distribute funds to the poor (fuqara), the needy (masakin), and wayfarers (ibn sabil). Despite its impactful niche, the organization maintains a <cite id="8">small board of only two members</cite>, which presents a governance risk that offsets its strong financial efficiency.
